title: 32-D
statement: D. Constellationtime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutA star map in Berland is a checked fieldn×msquares. In each square there is or there is not a star. The favourite constellation of all Berland's astronomers is the constellation of the Cross. This constellation can be formed by any 5 stars so, that for some integerx(radius of the constellation) the following is true:the 2nd is on the same vertical line as the 1st, butxsquares upthe 3rd is on the same vertical line as the 1st, butxsquares downthe 4th is on the same horizontal line as the 1st, butxsquares leftthe 5th is on the same horizontal line as the 1st, butxsquares rightSuch constellations can be very numerous, that's why they are numbered with integers from 1 on the following principle: when two constellations are compared, the one with a smaller radius gets a smaller index; if their radii are equal — the one, whose central star if higher than the central star of the other one; if their central stars are at the same level — the one, whose central star is to the left of the central star of the other one.Your task is to find the constellation with indexkby the given Berland's star map.InputThe first line contains three integersn,mandk(1 ≤n,m≤ 300, 1 ≤k≤ 3·107) — height and width of the map and index of the required constellation respectively. The upper-left corner has coordinates(1, 1), and the lower-right —(n,m). Then there follownlines,mcharacters each — description of the map.j-th character ini-th line is «*», if there is a star in the corresponding square, and «.» if this square is empty.OutputIf the number of the constellations is less thank, output-1. Otherwise output 5 lines, two integers each — coordinates of the required constellation. Output the stars in the following order: central, upper, lower, left, right.ExamplesInput5 6 1....*....***....*...*....***..Output2 51 53 52 42 6Input5 6 2....*....***....*...*....***..Output-1Input7 7 2...*.............*...*.***.*...*.............*...Output4 41 47 44 14 7

processed.result:
You are given a grid of size $n \times m$ representing a star map. Each cell in the grid can either contain a star ('*') or be empty ('.').  

A constellation is formed by 5 stars that follow a specific pattern:

* The 2nd star is vertically above the 1st star by a distance of $x$
* The 3rd star is vertically below the 1st star by a distance of $x$
* The 4th star is horizontally to the left of the 1st star by a distance of $x$
* The 5th star is horizontally to the right of the 1st star by a distance of $x$

Constellations are numbered based on their radius ($x$) and position. Constellations with smaller radii are numbered lower. If two constellations have the same radius, the one with the central star higher is numbered lower. If the central stars are at the same level, the one with the central star to the left is numbered lower.

Given the star map and a number $k$, find the coordinates of the $k$-th constellation. If there are fewer than $k$ constellations, output -1. 

Output the coordinates of the stars in the following order: central, upper, lower, left, right.

You are given a grid of stars and empty spaces.  Find the k-th constellation of stars that forms a cross shape.  A cross is defined by 5 stars arranged in a specific pattern.  If there are fewer than k constellations, output -1. Otherwise, output the coordinates of the k-th constellation.
